questions.question_text:
What is the following SQL command used for?

Select * from table(validate(t1, job_id => '_last'));

choices.A: To validate external table files in table t1 across all sessions
choices.C: To validate a file for errors before it gets executed using a COPY command
choices.B: To validate task SQL statements against table t1 in the last 14 days
choices.D: To return errors from the last executed COPY command into table t1 in the current session

discussion.content: D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
D. To return errors from the last executed COPY command into table t1 in the current session

Selected Answer: D
correct

Selected Answer: D
Validates the files loaded in a past execution of the COPY INTO <table> command and returns all the errors encountered during the load, rather than just the first error.

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/functions/validate.html

Selected Answer: D
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/functions/validate.html

choices.B: Query against a virtual warehouse cache
choices.A: Query against the result set cache
choices.C: Query against the most-recently created micro-partition

questions.question_text:
A sales table FCT_SALES has 100 million records.

The following query was executed:

SELECT COUNT (1) FROM FCT_SALES;

How did Snowflake fulfill this query?

discussion.content:
The COUNT(1) function is used to count all rows in the specified table. In Snowflake, using COUNT(1) is equivalent to using COUNT(*), as both provide a count of all rows without filtering based on any specific column. The number 1 is simply a placeholder; it does not affect the result. 

Snowflake optimizes this operation by using metadata statistics, allowing for quick retrieval of row counts without scanning every row.
D.Query against the metadata cache

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Correct

Selected Answer: D
D. Query against the metadata cache >> METADATA-BASED RESULT

Selected Answer: D
D. Query against the metadata cache

Selected Answer: A
**True.**

Snowflake's data warehouse was built from the ground up specifically for the cloud, rather than using an existing database or platform like Hadoop as a base. This design allows Snowflake to leverage the cloud's scalability, elasticity, and performance features, providing a modern data warehousing solution tailored for cloud environments.

Snowflake's data warehouse was built from the ground up specifically for the cloud, rather than being based on an existing database or platform like Hadoop. This design allows Snowflake to fully leverage the scalability, elasticity, and performance benefits of cloud infrastructure, offering unique features such as automatic scaling, data sharing, and a multi-cluster architecture.

questions.question_text: What happens when a virtual warehouse is resized?

choices.B: When reducing the size of a warehouse the compute resources are removed only when they are no longer being used to execute any current statements.
choices.D: Users who are trying to use the warehouse will receive an error message until the resizing is complete.
choices.C: The warehouse will be suspended while the new compute resource is provisioned and will resume automatically once provisioning is complete.
choices.A: When increasing the size of an active warehouse the compute resource for all running and queued queries on the warehouse are affected.

choices.B: Columns can be joined with an existing table.
choices.E: Data can be loaded without the need to spin up a virtual warehouse.
